summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ OIG interview with a former BOP correctional officer (subject) regarding her alleged misconduct, including false statements, job performance failure, security failure, and reporting false information, related to her duties at the MCC New York SHU during the period leading up to and including the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019. The interview covers her training, duties, interactions with staff and inmates, and specific events of August 9-10, 2019.

events.title: Epstein's first alleged suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein allegedly attempted to commit suicide while celled with Nicholas Tartaglione. He was subsequently placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein returned to SHU
events.description: Epstein was taken off psychological observation and returned to the SHU with instructions to be housed with an appropriate cellmate (Rafael Rodriguez).

events.title: Rodriguez removed from SHU
events.description: Inmate Rafael Rodriguez was removed from the MCC/SHU, leaving Jeffrey Epstein without a cellmate. The subject officer claims she was not notified.

events.title: Epstein's phone call in shower
events.description: Unit Manager Nathaniel Griffin placed Epstein in a shower cell to make an unmonitored phone call. Officer Michael Thomas later called to have the phone taken from him.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's body
events.description: Officer Michael Thomas discovered Jeffrey Epstein unresponsive in his cell during morning feeding, called for a cutter, performed CPR, and a medical emergency was declared.

events.title: Failure to conduct counts and rounds
events.description: The subject officer admits she and Officer Michael Thomas falsified count slips and round sheets for the 12:00 a.m., 3:00 a.m., and 5:00 a.m. counts/rounds, not conducting them.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview
events.description: The subject officer is interviewed under oath by DOJ OIG agents regarding alleged misconduct related to the Epstein case.

locations: Bergen County Bar Association, Hackensack, New Jersey (interview location)
keyFacts: The subject officer admits to falsifying official BOP records, including prepopulating round sheets and count slips for shifts where counts and rounds were not conducted, citing it as a common cultural practice at MCC.

The officer states she was never trained on, notified of, or provided with policies regarding the 'hotlist' for suicidal inmates, nor was she ever instructed that Jeffrey Epstein was required to have a cellmate at all times.

The officer claims she was the last person to see Epstein alive (around 10:00 p.m. on August 9, 2019) during a count, and that she did not know his cellmate, Rafael Rodriguez, had been removed from the SHU earlier that day.

The officer describes a dysfunctional and understaffed MCC culture where falsifying documents, inadequate training, and supervisors instructing staff to sign for training not received were commonplace.
The officer alleges that her supervisor, Lieutenant Tova Noel, directed her to sign SHU training documents she had not actually received because they were needed for a program review.
